Yet the merit and virtue thus cultivated, the benefits thus accrued—let us first urge the reception of scriptures. For the merit of such deeds, the fulfillment of such vows, may multiply a thousandfold, ten thousandfold. Yet when weighing the efficacy of virtuous practice, we find that no act of merit, no offering sown in fields of blessing, can compare to the reception and upholding of this scripture—even a single sentence, a single verse.

Thus far, we have extolled the supremacy of the scriptures to encourage devotion; below, we elucidate their purpose. Why is this so? This scripture is the path by which the perfected beings of the ten directions attain the Dao. It is the parent of all sages, the source from which all virtues arise, the way by which all who attain the Dao and achieve perfection must tread.

Next, we expound the benefits of upholding the scriptures. If there be a virtuous man or woman who awakens the natural intent of the Dao and receives and upholds this scripture, what blessing will not be theirs? What goodness will not follow?

Thus far, we have weighed the merit of virtuous deeds and urged the benefits of upholding the scriptures. Below, we lament the divergence between the wise and the foolish in their choices. Alas! People differ in lifespan, and minds differ in acuity. Some are swift, some slow; some minds are bright, others dim. The wise exert themselves tirelessly, ever fearing they fall short; the foolish turn away and slander, their thoughts as distant as Mount Tai. How can such disparity be resolved?

Here ends the lament of the sage; below, we urge the transmission of the teachings. Lord Dao commanded: "You, Dao-ling, shall transmit this scripture to later disciples, guiding them into the gate of the Dao." When the Most High entrusted the Heavenly Master with the transmission of this scripture to later learners, there were signs of their destined union with the perfected. Whether in broad strokes or fine detail, one must weigh the essentials, that the filth of the heart may be cleansed and all may return to the chamber of the Dao.

Thus far, we have recounted past errors and urged their abandonment. What follows is the third section, which clarifies the harm of evil deeds and urges repentance. Within this section, there are two parts: first, the Heavenly Master’s inquiry, and second, the Dao Lord’s response.

The first part is further divided: first, the assembly of immortals present at the reception of the Dharma, and second, the circumstances of the inquiry. We begin with the immortals gathered at the time of the Dharma’s reception.

At that time, Dao-ling received the Dharma. All the great sages, Brahma-heaven Daoists, perfected beings of wondrous conduct, and envoys of the Heavenly Worthies of the ten directions—seven hundred million in all—gathered before the Dao to praise Dao-ling. Amidst the assembly, Dao-ling, adorned in ritual vestments, stood with hands clasped before the Dao and inquired about the causes of calamity and fortune.

Dao-ling said: "I observe that among all who revere the Dao and uphold the Dharma, some encounter disasters, sudden illnesses, or violent deaths; some face official summons, slander, or misfortune; their endeavors fail, their desires go unfulfilled. I do not know whether such afflictions arise from past karmic causes or present transgressions. I humbly beseech your illumination to clarify what remains obscure."

The Venerable Lord replied: "Such misfortunes arise from human wickedness, and they are also the result of past lives. Why is this so? Though people revere the Dao, their devotion is not earnest. Though they know the Dao is supreme and wish to follow it, their conduct and nature remain no different from the vulgar. They do not cast aside deceit and falsehood, yet seek to approach the true and perfected with such impurity—this can never succeed. The true and the deceitful are as incompatible as thieves and watchful guards. Though they profess to follow the great Dao, they also pray to evil spirits, their hearts wavering between two paths, thus aligning themselves with the false. Such people, though nominally followers of the Dao, hope for its protection, yet the Dao does not accept them. Clinging to demonic influences, they claim allegiance to the Dao. When disaster, illness, misfortune, or peril strike, they expect the Dao to shield them, yet the Dao does not save them. Demonic spirits and malevolent ghosts assail them, and the Dao does not intervene. Their bodies meet death, their families face ruin. Yet these foolish and vulgar people fail to awaken, turning instead to resentment, declaring the Dao powerless. Even if they do not speak it aloud, their hearts harbor bitterness and reproach."

How can such people fail to rectify their conduct, transform their hearts, and immerse themselves in the passage of days and months, hoping to avert calamity? Not one in ten thousand shall be spared. Stubborn in their perverse nature, their hearts unchanged, upon the end of their lives, they shall descend into the Three Paths and Five Sufferings—then, what use is regret?

How grievous are these foolish and vulgar ones, who revere the false and belittle the true! Why do they not purify their hearts and renew themselves here and now? The wise hold fast to true faith, cultivating and upholding the scriptures and precepts.

The Great Dao is most revered, lofty and without peer, boundless and all-encompassing, enfolding heaven and earth. It governs the host of spirits, gives life to the myriad things—from the soaring and creeping to all creatures that breathe—all are brought forth by the Dao. The majestic spirit of the Dao gathers all, disperses all, dissolves all, accomplishes all, and subdues all. It grasps the pivot of heaven’s mechanism, commands the myriad spirits, precedes all that is prior, and exhausts all that is boundless.

Humans dwell within it, their years and lives fleeting as the blink of an eye. All things are perfected by the Dao, all things arise from the Dao. It pities and cherishes all beings as a mother grieves for her child. Thus, it sets forth the laws for humanity, bidding them cultivate the Dao and practice its ways. Those who achieve great merit ascend as immortals; those of middling merit attain the Mud-Pill Palace; those of lesser merit extend their years.

Such towering rewards, yet people remain unaware, sinking together in delusion, refusing to cast off their vulgar deceits. For this, I shed tears and speak these verses:

In past lives, they sowed evil seeds,
In this life, they accumulate no pure fragrance.
Clinging to the false while professing the Dao,
They invite misfortune and ill fate.
True qi lends no strength,
While evil brings only disaster.
When the Three Calamities arrive as one,
Their families are ruined, their bodies perish.
Seven generations of ancestors sink into the Three Bureaus,
Their souls and spirits dragged away.
They tread upon the Mountain of Knives,
Their hands wounded by the Forest of Swords.
Above and below, the Five Courts of Suffering,
Blood flows, festering into sores.
For ten thousand kalpas, no pardon is granted,
As they revolve through the Five Paths’ grounds.
Yet if there are those who follow the precepts,
The Heavenly Officials shall descend to welcome them.

chunks.original_text: 当天师受法之时，有十方大圣、道士、真人及异境天尊遣使称叹，或腾云御日，策驾乘台，总有七千亿人同在升玄座下。 此列时众讫，自此下次序诸问事由。 就此门中，分为两别：初举果以征因，次问因以明果。 初但问因。 道陵伏见，奉道奉法至所求不得。 世人奉道奉法，应蒙圣力护持，因何逢祸遇灾，危亡不少。 或有暴病卒死，缧绁横加，作事弗成，诸不吉利。 此承果征因讫，次问因以明果。 不审此等何所触犯，未晓如此之辈所从而来，为是当身造愆，为是宿世殃咎。 愿垂问讫，自此以下老君答释。 就答中文，即有长行偈诵。 就长行中，大分为三：第一，先物恶业，第二，次劝拾恶，第三，即劝修道。 前文为二：初明其稔恶，次劝其改悔。 初文复二：先物恶因，次释恶行。 今正是初，老君答曰，此辈皆由人恶。 亦是宿世。 如此壈坎之辈，亦有二种因缘，是己身自招，二是宿世殃及。 物恶因讫，次释恶行。 何以故世人奉道不勤至而未见趣。 向乃心起怨望，进退犹豫，无有至诚。 或存或亡，二心不定。 闻道尊胜，欣而奉之； 俗行未除，仍怀邪伪，欲希真道，何可得焉。 不知邪遇正真，如盗贼之逢监伺。 以其心不专固，上天遂与之邪。 以其染附邪精，至道便当不佑。 纵使遇灾遭病，亦不为摄，邪精所得，身致死亡，家门破灭。 愚痴世俗殊不觉悟，乃更言道无神，心内怨望。 上来明恶业讫，自下劝其改悔。 此辈何不庄治事至悔复可及。 何不庄治戒行，选易心肠。 濡浸於邪，日复一日。 天网恢恢，疏而不失，赏善罚恶，万无一遗。 因何子戾，汝心不能思罪补过，命没幽沉恶趣，悔恨何所及焉。 此劝悔过讫，下劝拾恶。 痛哉愚俗至於此自新。 大圣大慈伤痛愚俗，何忍崇邪轻道，不肯奉戒修真。 胡不洗弃恶心，於此新兴善行。 上来举恶劝拾讫，自下举道劝修。 就劝修文中，分为四别：一明道尊胜故须修； 二道有势力故须修； 三道能生成故须修； 四道有利益故须修胜道。 今先明道尊胜。 贤者正心，修奉经戒，大道至尊，至皆是道生。 贤智之者，宜各正心，奉受大经，勤修上道。 道法尊妙，不可思议。 天地禀以长存，万类以之成育。 大则周圆无外，小则细入微间。 道法如此尊高，贤者那不修奉。 下辩势力。 道之威神何所不集至穷於无穷。 大道神力，何所不招，何所不禳，何所不伏。 把天机关枢要，驱使一切鬼神。 先则先乎无先，穷则穷於无极。 此明道有势力讫，下明道能生成。 人处其间，年命奄忽，至令修道行。 人处天地之间，虽复命有长短，皆是道之生成。 大道愍念於人，若母见伤於子，殷懃演说经戒，普令修道学仙。 此明道成益讫，下品量功行。 功上者仙至不改俗伪。 此明随功深浅，福报不差，而人弗知，为恶不改，相与沦没，望返无期。 大圣悲怜，为之泣涕，故留经戒，劝舍恶心。 上来此长行文讫，自下偈颂。 就偈颂文中，分为三别：初有一行诵恶因，次有一行诵恶果，后有一行劝修道。 今且诵恶业。 宿世缘植恶至招致不吉良。 宿世种植恶缘，积生不曾香洁，染邪而言奉道，招致故不吉。 此诵恶因讫，次诵恶果。 真炁不为力至展转五道场。 真炁不为势力，邪恶反成殃咎，三灾一时临逼，家破身致死亡，七祖沦坠三官，魂魄相牵，流曳刀山，令其足践，剑树令其手攀，上下五苦之庭，脓疮流血遍体，万劫不蒙原赦，展转五道之中。

When the Heavenly Master received the Daoist teachings, the Ten Directions’ Great Sages, Daoist masters, Perfected Ones, and Transcendent Lords of wondrous realms dispatched envoys to offer praise. Some rode clouds or harnessed the sun, steering chariots upon celestial terraces—seven hundred billion in all, gathered beneath the Ascending Mystery Seat. Once this assembly had taken their places, the proceedings turned to the sequence of inquiries below.

Within this discourse, two distinctions are made: first, the effect is raised to trace its cause; next, the cause is examined to clarify its effect. The initial inquiry concerns the cause.

Dao-ling observed that those who devotedly follow the Dao and its precepts often fail to attain their desires. Though the world’s people uphold the Dao and its laws, and should be shielded by sacred power, why do they so frequently encounter misfortune, calamity, and peril—even untimely death? Some succumb to sudden illness, others to unjust imprisonment; their endeavors fail, and nothing prospers. This concludes the inquiry into effects to trace their causes. Next, the cause is examined to clarify the effect.

It remains unclear what offenses these individuals have committed. Are their sufferings the result of present transgressions or karmic retribution from past lives? With this question posed, the Most High Lord Lao begins His response.

Within His answer, prose and verse intermingle. The prose is divided into three main sections: first, the enumeration of evil deeds; second, the exhortation to abandon evil; and third, the encouragement to cultivate the Dao. The first section is further divided into two parts: first, the exposition of evil’s origins, and second, the explanation of evil’s manifestations.

Now addressing the first part, Lord Lao replies: Such afflictions arise from human wickedness, rooted in past lives. These troubled souls fall into two categories: those who bring suffering upon themselves, and those upon whom past-life misfortunes descend.

Having outlined the origins of evil, the text proceeds to explain its manifestations. Why do those who follow the Dao with insufficient diligence fail to perceive its rewards? Initially, they may grow resentful, wavering in their commitment, lacking sincerity. Their devotion flickers, their resolve falters. Though they hear of the Dao’s exalted nature and rejoice in its pursuit, they have not shed worldly ways; their hearts remain tainted by deceit. How can they attain the true Dao while clinging to falsehood? When the false encounters the true, it is like a thief meeting a watchful guard. Because their hearts are not steadfast, Heaven allows evil to take hold. As they cling to corrupt spirits, the true Dao withholds its protection. Even when disaster or illness strikes, no aid is granted; the corrupt spirits prevail, leading to bodily death and the ruin of their households. Yet the foolish, worldly masses remain oblivious, even declaring the Dao powerless and harboring resentment.

This concludes the exposition of evil deeds; what follows is the exhortation to repent. Why do these individuals not rectify their conduct while repentance is still possible? Why do they not refine their precepts and transform their hearts? Day by day, they steep themselves in corruption. Heaven’s net is vast and wide-meshed, yet nothing escapes it; rewards for good and punishments for evil are meted out without exception. Why do you persist in perversity? If you cannot reflect on your transgressions and make amends, your life will end in the dark depths of evil destinies—what use will regret be then?

Having urged repentance, the text next exhorts the abandonment of evil. How pitiable are the foolish masses, who persist in error to this extent! The Great Sage, in boundless compassion, grieves for their plight. How can they bear to revere falsehood and belittle the Dao, refusing to uphold the precepts and cultivate truth? Why not wash away wickedness and renew yourselves with virtuous deeds?

Having enumerated evil and urged its abandonment, the text turns to the Dao to encourage its cultivation. This section is divided into four parts: first, the Dao’s exalted nature demands cultivation; second, the Dao’s power demands cultivation; third, the Dao’s creative capacity demands cultivation; and fourth, the Dao’s benefits demand its pursuit.

First, the Dao’s exalted nature: The worthy must rectify their hearts, uphold the scriptures and precepts, for the Great Dao is most revered—all things arise from it. The wise and discerning should align their hearts, receive the great scriptures, and diligently cultivate the supreme Dao. The Dao’s laws are sublime and beyond comprehension. Heaven and Earth endure by its grace; the myriad beings flourish through its nurture. Vast, it encompasses all without limit; subtle, it enters the infinitesimal. Given the Dao’s lofty and wondrous nature, why do the worthy not cultivate and uphold it?

Next, the Dao’s power: The Dao’s numinous might extends everywhere, even to the boundless. Its divine power summons all, averts all, subdues all. It grasps the celestial mechanisms, commands all spirits. It precedes all precedence, exhausts all limits. This concludes the explanation of the Dao’s power.

Next, the Dao’s creative capacity: Though human lifespans are fleeting, one must cultivate the Dao and practice its ways. Though lives vary in length, all exist within the Dao’s creation. The Great Dao, like a mother grieving for her child, earnestly expounds the scriptures and precepts, urging all to cultivate the Dao and study immortality.

Having explained the Dao’s benefits, the text proceeds to assess merit and conduct. Those whose merit is supreme ascend as immortals. This illustrates how the depth of one’s merit determines the measure of one’s reward—yet people remain unaware, persisting in evil without reform, sinking together into ruin, with no hope of return. The Great Sage, moved by compassion, weeps for them and leaves behind scriptures and precepts, exhorting them to abandon wickedness.

This concludes the prose; what follows are the verses. The verses are divided into three parts: first, a single line on the causes of evil; next, a single line on the effects of evil; and finally, a single line exhorting the cultivation of the Dao.

First, the causes of evil:
In past lives, they sowed evil seeds,
In this life, they accumulate no pure fragrance.
Clinging to the false while professing the Dao,
They invite misfortune and ill fate.

This concludes the verse on evil’s causes; next, the verse on evil’s effects:
True qi lends no strength,
While evil brings only disaster.
When the Three Calamities arrive as one,
Their families are ruined, their bodies perish.
Seven generations of ancestors sink into the Three Bureaus,
Their souls and spirits dragged away.
They tread upon the Mountain of Knives,
Their hands wounded by the Forest of Swords.
Above and below, the Five Courts of Suffering,
Blood flows, festering into sores.
For ten thousand kalpas, no pardon is granted,
As they revolve through the Five Paths’ grounds.

chunks.original_text: 此举恶劝拾讫，下劝修道。 若有科法子，天官降相迎。 若有科法之子，天官降下迎之，鸾舆霭霭云中，龙车峨峨空裹。 上来至此总明离过文讫，自此以下是大段第三文，劝立善功。 就此文中，凡有三别：初长行，以劝立功； 次偈颂文，以劝立行道； 说偈毕，下举益以劝。 就长行文中，分为四别：第一劝改过，第二劝立功，第三劝修行，第四明得益。 就改过文中，又为二意； 初劝改恶以存念，次劝持经以悔过。 初文又二：先劝舍恶，次劝念道。 先明改破恶。 道言：天下男女违背真正，不从教戒，但贪爱欲、富贵荣禄、色利财宝，饮酒食肉，恣心快意，骄奢盈溢，岂念道乎？ 人常念道，道亦念人。 人之若鱼，道之若水，鱼得水而生，失水而死。 道炁不居，人身则虚#14； 人身既虚，何得久生乎？ 要在精进，存念至真。 告诸贤者，欲得保命度身，得道成真者，当宗受《无上灵宝升玄内教真一真经》，皆当洗心，除去先日所犯罪过，革修后善，以顺经法。 能如是者，即合无上正真道意。 凡为道者，除过立功，思罪补愆。 若未见经法之前，或手杀人者，当救应垂死者一人以赎之。 於罪既除，又得活人之功。 若曾行劫盗#15、得他财物，今受法后，当心与口誓#16，以私财贿，施散贫乏，建立功德。 於责既解，又得施惠之报。 若以口言谗谤胜已，谮#17杀贤善，枉说无罪者，进达贤人以当之。 於负既了，又得进贤之对。 转祸为福，此真要言。 尔乃道行既立，言令必珍。 见人有失，转相劝戒，宣传经法，普度天人。 令诸男女咸得法利。 如此功报，甚为无量。 勿谓道之无形，以为傲慢，但当庄事修勤，晨夜清净。 若见人民疾病，当相救度，不得以智欺愚，乘威假诈，倚托鬼神，恐吓天民，取他财物； 才有小知，称名自大，轻忽愚贱，更相毁訾。 不得背向调论，指擿贤者。 不得私情贪狠，敬贵耻贱，乐富弃贫，诈望意气，爱憎二心。 不欲随情请福，以为惠施。 道终不从，鬼不为使，毁败正法，身反受咎。 当同志相求，同法相好。 若男女不解书疏者，但受经法，专心好道，听诵经戒#18，会於斋堂，谛受勿忘。 亦可堂上烧香，清净在座，男女有别，俨然正体，安神精心，明听法音。 勿妄华言，倾斜不端。 游心他念，懒惰睡眠，两两相对，哗语暔暔，劳形自役，当苦无获#19。 若能如法精肃，则受福无量，侍经仙官自来护人，终已无灾，得道升天。 太上老君乃说偈曰#20： 宗虚尊大乘，色欲俱然绝。 要从精进起，邪魔无由列。 转祸修德行，宿负自然灭。 功积随日新，超然与俗别。 言令必珍用，大勋由此结。 世有愚恶人，称名设鬼教。 私情诈公行，万言无一效。 任心行魔事，自尔招大考。 不知所由犯，欻以致残暴。 魂囚酆都庭，痛毒於斯到。 必有乐法者，信心寄因缘。 虽不晓文字，心识意在敦。 虚心彻邪念，听诵数千言。 专心致得道，遂成无上真。 但能受持想，功德自弥天。 一切善男子， 注心听吾经。 勿复相对论，好为无至情#21。 一则乱至教，二则 劳身形。 劳形当自苦#22，爱报不聪明。 好当自恭肃，勿复轻神灵。 见有精进者，升仙补天官。 高蹈凌梵外，学致甚不难。 何为守浊美，不希腾形神。

Here follows the translation:

---

This concludes the admonition against evil; next, the exhortation to cultivate the Dao.

Should there be disciples of the precepts and laws,
Heavenly officials descend to welcome them.
If there are disciples of the precepts and laws,
Heavenly officials descend to greet them,
Phoenix chariots drifting in misty clouds,
Dragon carriages towering amidst the void.

From the above to this point concludes the exposition on avoiding transgressions. What follows is the third major section, urging the establishment of meritorious deeds.

Within this section, there are three distinctions:
First, the prose exposition, to urge the establishment of merit;
Next, the verse and hymn, to urge the practice of the Dao;
After the verse, examples of benefits are given to encourage.

Within the prose exposition, there are four distinctions:
First, the exhortation to reform transgressions;
Second, the exhortation to establish merit;
Third, the exhortation to cultivate practice;
Fourth, the clarification of benefits obtained.

Within the section on reforming transgressions, there are two intentions:
First, to urge the abandonment of evil and the preservation of mindfulness;
Next, to urge the upholding of scriptures for repentance.

The first part has two aspects:
First, to urge the abandonment of evil;
Next, to urge mindfulness of the Dao.

First, the correction of past transgressions is explained.

The Dao says: Men and women of the world, turning away from the true and correct, disobeying teachings and precepts, indulge only in lust, desire, wealth, honor, glory, sensual pleasures, riches, wine, and meat. They follow their hearts’ desires, acting with arrogance and excess—how could they ever contemplate the Dao?

When people constantly contemplate the Dao, the Dao also contemplates them.
People are like fish, the Dao like water—
Fish live when they obtain water, and die when they lose it.
If the qi of the Dao does not reside within,
The human body becomes empty;
When the body is empty, how can it endure for long?
The key lies in diligent progress, preserving mindfulness of the utmost truth.

I address all worthy ones: If you wish to preserve your life, transcend the mortal form, attain the Dao, and achieve true perfection, you should revere and receive *The Supreme Numinous Treasure Scripture of Ascending Mystery and the Inner Teachings of the True One*. You must purify your hearts, eliminate past transgressions, reform and cultivate future goodness, and align with the scriptural laws.

Those who can do this accord with the intent of the Supreme Orthodox and True Dao.

All who follow the Dao must eliminate transgressions, establish merit, reflect on their sins, and make amends for their faults.

If, before encountering the scriptural laws, you have killed with your own hands, you should save and revive one person on the verge of death to atone for it.
Once the transgression is eliminated, you also gain the merit of saving a life.

If you have committed robbery or theft, taking others’ property, after receiving the Dharma, you should vow with heart and mouth, using your private wealth to bestow alms upon the poor and establish meritorious deeds.
Once the debt is resolved, you also gain the reward of bestowing kindness.

If you have slandered those superior to yourself with your words, falsely accused and harmed the worthy and good, or wrongly accused the innocent, you should promote and elevate the worthy to make amends.
Once the burden is settled, you also gain the recompense of advancing the virtuous.

Turning misfortune into fortune—these are the essential words.

Thus, when the practice of the Dao is established, your words and commands must be treasured.
When you see others making mistakes, admonish and exhort one another, propagate the scriptural Dharma, and universally deliver gods and humans.
Let all men and women obtain the benefits of the Dharma.
Such meritorious rewards are immeasurable.

Do not claim the Dao is formless and act with arrogance and disdain. Instead, devote yourself to diligent cultivation, maintaining purity day and night.
If you see people suffering from illness, you should save and deliver them.
Do not deceive the foolish with cunning, exploit power to feign deceit, rely on ghosts and spirits to intimidate the people, or seize others’ property.
Do not boast of minor knowledge, claim greatness, belittle the foolish and lowly, or slander one another.
Do not engage in frivolous discussions, pointing out the faults of the worthy.
Do not harbor private greed and malice, respecting the noble while shaming the humble, favoring the rich while abandoning the poor, or feigning generosity for personal gain.
Do not seek blessings by following personal desires, considering it benevolence.
The Dao will never comply, ghosts will not serve you, and if you destroy the true Dharma, you will suffer the consequences yourself.

Strive to seek those of like mind, befriend those of the same Dharma.

If men and women cannot read or write, simply receive the scriptural Dharma, devote your hearts to the Dao, listen to the recitation of scriptures and precepts, gather in the fasting hall, and attentively receive without forgetting.
You may also burn incense in the hall, sit in purity, maintaining separation between men and women, with solemn and proper demeanor. Calm your spirits, concentrate your minds, and listen clearly to the sounds of the Dharma.
Do not speak frivolously, lean or slouch improperly.
Do not let your minds wander to other thoughts, grow lazy, or fall asleep. Do not face each other, chattering noisily, exhausting your bodies with self-imposed labor, suffering without gain.

If you can be reverent and solemn according to the Dharma, you will receive boundless blessings. The immortal officials who attend the scriptures will naturally come to protect you, ensuring you remain free from disaster and attain the Dao to ascend to heaven.

Then, the Most High Lord Lao spoke in verse:

Revere emptiness and honor the Great Vehicle,
Severing both form and desire.
The essentials arise from diligent progress,
Leaving no place for demonic forces to array.
Transform misfortune by cultivating virtuous conduct,
And past debts naturally vanish.
Merit accumulates and renews daily,
Transcending the mundane with distinction.
Words and commands must be treasured and employed,
Great merit is thereby established.
There are foolish and evil people in the world
Who invoke names and establish ghostly teachings.
They practice private deceit in public conduct,
A thousand words yield not a single effect.
Indulging their hearts in demonic affairs,
They bring upon themselves great trials.
Unknowing of the source of their transgressions,
They suddenly meet with ruin and violence.
Their souls are imprisoned in the courts of Fengdu,
Where pain and poison arrive in full.
Yet there are those who delight in the Dharma,
Entrusting their faith to causes and conditions.
Though they may not understand written words,
Their hearts recognize the intent within.
Empty their minds of perverse thoughts,
Listening to the recitation of thousands of words.
Devoting their hearts, they attain the Dao,
Thus becoming Supreme Perfected Ones.
Simply by upholding and contemplating,
Their merit naturally fills the heavens.

All good men,
Focus your minds and listen to my scripture.
Do not engage in idle discussions,
Or act without sincerity.
First, it disrupts the supreme teachings;
Second, it exhausts the body.
Exhausting the body brings self-suffering,
And the reward for love is not wisdom.
You should be reverent and solemn,
Do not slight the divine spirits.
When you see those who diligently progress,
They ascend as immortals to fill heavenly offices.
Soaring beyond the Brahma realms,
Their learning is not at all difficult.
Why cling to the impurities of the world,
And not aspire to transcend form and spirit?

---

chunks.original_text: 金阙不乐游，相与隶北门。 吾见五苦徒，悲叫刀山巅，面目无人姿，乞食饿鬼间。 天罚备常加#23，受考弥劫年。 盖由不积善，谤毁害真贤。 对报在须臾，愚人谓不然。 苟作不自革，独自落天残。 未若修弘道，众真与尔群。 世间男之与女并悉违背正真，不能奉戒持经，唯贪荣华富贵，酒肉快其情意，财色恣其心怀； 但知盈溢骄奢，岂有一人念道。 此劝改恶讫，次劝存念。 有法说喻，俾人常念道，道亦念人。 但能念於道，道岂不念於人。 示喻明说，人之若鱼之在水，至失水而死。 故《西升经》云：人在道中，道在人中。 鱼在水中，水在鱼中。 道去人死，水乾鱼命终。 即是此义。 下合喻，以劝修道。 道炁不居，人身则空，至存念至真。 道炁既远，人身则空。 人身既空，岂得长久。 要须勤修上道，存念至真。 此劝改恶存念讫，下劝持经以除过。 文为三：第一劝持经，第二劝除过，第三明得道。 今先劝经。 告诸贤者，欲得保命度身，至真一真经。 道告贤者，子欲命度身成真得道者，当须宗受《升玄灵宝真一真经》经力扶持，自然得道。 此劝受经讫，次劝除过。 皆当洗心至以顺经法。 当洗除垢，思罪补愆，唯道是从，唯法是务。 此劝除过讫，下明得道。 能如是者，即合无上正真道意。 若能顺道无违，则与至理冥合。 故《道经》云：同於道者，道亦得之。 即是此义。 上来劝改过讫，自下劝立善功。 就立功文中，分为五别：第一劝赎生，第二劝散施，第三劝进贤，第四明立功得益，第五结劝。 今先劝赎生。 凡为道者除过立功至又得活人之功。 凡欲结身为道，当须除过立功。 或未持经戒之前，亲行手杀，当救垂死之命以补前愆，即於宿负得除，又获济他之福。 此劝赎生讫，下劝散施。 若曾行劫盗得他财物至又得施惠之报。 或未闻经法之前，劫夺他物，今当心与口誓，思过责愆，以己私财贿施於贫乏，植种福田，建立功德，於其前债既了，又得施惠之功。 此散施。 说劝进贤，若以口言谗谤胜己至又得进贤之对。 或曾经谗谤胜己，赞毁贤能，枉谗无辜，嫉妬君子者，当以荐达贤人，称扬硕学，於其前负得除，又获进贤之对。 下明立功得益，转祸为福。 此真要言至甚为无量，劝转恶心，修於福善。 道行既立，言令必珍。 若见人有过失，即须为说经戒，咸令男子、女人一切蒙法利益。 如此功报巍巍，其为无边无量。 此举利益讫，下设戒劝。 勿谓道之无形以为傲慢至晨夜清净。 莫谓大道无形，而欲轻忽傲慢，但当庄事修勤，晨夜清心净虑。 上来至此劝修善立功讫，自此以下，正劝离过。 行有二别：初劝改过，次劝修善。 先劝改过。 若见人民疾病当相救度至身及受咎。 见人有忧，助为作福，有救度念得安稳，不得以智欺愚，倚托神鬼恐吓天下，取他财物，薄有神智，调弄贤人，轻忽於下，更相谤毁，敬贵耻贱，乐富弃贫，爱憎二心，诈望意气，不肯随顺人情以为惠施，纵欲驱除。 谨案神鬼亦不从之，於正法诚无效验，身反受於殃咎。 此劝改过讫，次劝修道。 当同志相求同法相好至病苦无获。 当须同法相好，同志相求，宗受大经，专心乐道。 必其未明法教，当就明者决之，听诵谛受，勿使遗忘。 又须尊居俨然，安神正体，不得游心他念，玩堕睡眠，相对闲语喃喃，毕竟都无所获。

The Golden Gates offer no joy in wandering,
Together we serve at the Northern Portal.
I see the fivefold sufferers’ torment—
Wailing atop the Knife Mountain’s peak,
Their faces bereft of human semblance,
Begging among the hungry ghosts.
Heaven’s punishments are ever applied,
Enduring trials through kalpas unending.
This comes from failing to accumulate goodness,
Slandering and harming the true and worthy.
Retribution arrives in an instant,
Yet fools insist it is not so.
If one does not reform oneself,
They alone fall to heaven’s ruin.

Far better to cultivate the great Dao,
Joining the host of Perfected Ones.
In this world, men and women alike
All turn from the true and upright,
Unable to uphold precepts or scriptures,
Only craving glory, wealth, and honor,
Indulging in wine and meat to please their hearts,
Letting wealth and desire fill their minds.
They know only excess, pride, and extravagance—
Not one among them thinks of the Dao.

This first urges reform of evil,
Next urges the keeping of mindfulness.
There is a dharma with parable,
That people may always think of the Dao,
And the Dao will think of them in return.
If one can think of the Dao,
How could the Dao not think of them?
The analogy is made clear:
People are like fish within water—
When the water is lost, they die.
Thus the *Scripture of Western Ascension* says:
People are within the Dao, the Dao within people;
Fish are within water, water within fish.
When the Dao departs, people die;
When water dries, the fish’s life ends.
This is the meaning.
Below, the analogy is applied
To urge the cultivation of the Dao.
When the Dao’s qi does not abide,
The human body becomes empty.
If one maintains mindfulness of the utmost truth,
The Dao’s qi will not depart,
And the body will not become empty.
If the body is empty,
How can it endure long?
One must diligently cultivate the supreme Dao,
Maintaining mindfulness of the utmost truth.

This urges reform of evil and keeping of mindfulness.
Next, it urges upholding scriptures to eliminate transgressions.
The text is divided into three parts:
First, urging the upholding of scriptures;
Second, urging the elimination of transgressions;
Third, clarifying attainment of the Dao.
First, urging the scriptures:
It tells all worthy ones,
If you wish to preserve life and transcend the self,
You must revere the *True One Scripture of Ascending Mystery and Numinous Treasure*.
The Dao tells the worthy:
If you desire life, transcendence, and attainment of the Dao,
You must honor and receive the *True One Scripture of Ascending Mystery and Numinous Treasure*.
Its power will sustain you,
And you will naturally attain the Dao.

This urges the receiving of scriptures.
Next, urging the elimination of transgressions:
All should purify their hearts
To accord with the scripture’s dharma.
They must wash away filth,
Reflect on their faults, and make amends,
Following only the Dao,
Devoting themselves only to the dharma.

This urges the elimination of transgressions.
Below, it clarifies attainment of the Dao:
Those who can do this
Accord with the intent of the supreme true Dao.
If one follows the Dao without deviation,
They merge with the utmost principle.
Thus the *Daoist Scripture* says:
Those who are one with the Dao,
The Dao also attains them.
This is the meaning.

The above urges reform of transgressions.
Below, it urges the establishment of meritorious deeds.
Within the section on establishing merit,
There are five distinctions:
First, urging the ransoming of lives;
Second, urging almsgiving;
Third, urging the promotion of the worthy;
Fourth, clarifying the benefits of establishing merit;
Fifth, concluding exhortations.
First, urging the ransoming of lives:
All who would embody the Dao
Must eliminate transgressions and establish merit,
Even gaining the merit of reviving others.
All who wish to embody the Dao
Must eliminate transgressions and establish merit.
If before upholding scriptures and precepts,
They personally committed killing,
They should save those on the verge of death
To make amends for past faults.
Thus, their karmic debts are erased,
And they also gain the blessing of aiding others.

This urges the ransoming of lives.
Next, urging almsgiving:
If they once robbed others of their wealth,
They should also gain the reward of bestowing kindness.
If before hearing the scriptures’ dharma,
They plundered others’ possessions,
They should now vow in heart and word,
Reflect on their faults, and make amends.
With their own private wealth,
They should bestow alms upon the poor,
Planting seeds in the field of blessings,
Establishing merit and virtue.
Thus, their past debts are settled,
And they also gain the merit of bestowing kindness.

This urges almsgiving.
Next, urging the promotion of the worthy:
If they once slandered those superior to themselves,
They should also gain the reward of promoting the worthy.
If they ever slandered those superior to themselves,
Praised the unworthy, or defamed the innocent,
Envying and resenting the noble,
They should now recommend and elevate the worthy,
Extolling those of great learning.
Thus, their past debts are erased,
And they also gain the reward of promoting the worthy.

Below, clarifying the benefits of establishing merit,
Turning misfortune into blessing:
These are true and essential words—
Their merit is immeasurable.
It urges turning from evil thoughts
To cultivate blessings and goodness.
When the Dao’s practice is established,
Its words must be treasured.
If one sees others’ faults,
They should expound the scriptures and precepts,
Enabling all—men and women alike—
To receive the dharma’s benefits.
Such merit is towering,
Boundless and immeasurable.

This clarifies the benefits.
Below, it sets forth admonitions and exhortations:
Do not think the Dao formless and become arrogant,
But diligently cultivate with reverence,
Maintaining purity of heart day and night.

The above urges the cultivation of goodness and establishment of merit.
Below, it properly urges the abandonment of transgressions.
There are two distinctions:
First, urging reform of transgressions;
Second, urging cultivation of goodness.
First, urging reform of transgressions:
If one sees people suffering from illness,
They should save and deliver them.
Seeing others in distress,
Assist them in performing blessings.
With a mind to save and deliver,
They may attain peace and stability.
Do not use cunning to deceive the foolish,
Relying on spirits and ghosts to frighten the world,
Extorting others’ wealth.
Though possessing some spiritual insight,
Do not manipulate the worthy,
Disdain the lowly,
Slander one another,
Respect the noble and shame the humble,
Delight in wealth and abandon the poor,
Hold love and hatred in duality,
Deceive with false expectations,
Refuse to follow others’ sentiments to bestow kindness,
Or indulge desires and drive others away.
Carefully consider:
Even spirits and ghosts will not comply,
And in the true dharma, there is truly no efficacy.
Instead, one’s own body will suffer calamity.

This urges reform of transgressions.
Next, urging cultivation of the Dao:
Those of like aspiration should seek one another,
Those of like dharma should befriend one another.
They must honor and receive the great scriptures,
Devoting their hearts to delighting in the Dao.
If the dharma’s teachings are not yet clear,
They should consult those who understand,
Listening and reciting with careful reception,
Not allowing forgetfulness.
They must also maintain solemn dignity,
Calming the spirit and aligning the body,
Not letting the mind wander to other thoughts,
Or indulge in drowsiness and slumber,
Engaging in idle chatter face to face—
In the end, they will gain nothing.

chunks.original_text: 此劝修离过行讫，下明得益。 若能如法精肃则受福无量至得道升天。 若能精肃如法，则受福无穷，侍经仙官自来拥护，非唯终身无咎，乃至得升天堂。 上来至此长行文讫，自此已下偈诵，以劝立功。 就偈诵文中，分为别：初有两行半颂，立功得益。 世有愚痴下有两行半颂，行恶有损。 必有乐法下有五行劝持经。 见有精进，下有五行半，举善对恶，以劝取舍。 今先诵持经。 宗虚尊大乘至邪魔无由列。 宗奉虚无，尊承大法。 荣色俱绝并除，精进既起内心，外魔敢能列其过恶？ 此劝立功讫，下明得益。 转祸修德行至大勋由此结。 若得弃粗心，革修善行，则宿昔愆负自尔云消，功德巍巍，随日而进，超然轻举，与世别殊。 人必遵行大勋，由斯结矣。 此明立功益讫，次明行恶获损。 世有愚痴人至万言无一效。 世有愚痴之人，称名而设鬼教，私诈公然行之，万语无一信实。 此明行恶讫，次明损失。 任心行魔事至痛毒於斯到。 恣已愚情而行魔事，赃满罪定，殃考自来，不知死日所由，欻然而致残暴，魂囚酆都鬼庭，痛毒於斯邪。 此明行恶政损讫，自下劝修经法。 文为二：前颂信法人，后颂听受之者。 先诵行法人。 必有乐法者，至听诵数千言。 必有乐法之者敬信，以善为缘，虽不能晓文字，用心而在敦重，虚豁是非，听诵章句。 此明信法，下明得益。 专心致得，道至功德自弥天。 专心政得仙道，遂成无上至真，但能受持妙经，功德自然广大。 上来诵信受人讫，下诵听法者。 一切善男女注心听吾经至勿复轻神灵。 道言，一切男女人，各注心听经，勿复相对妄说无有颠倒之意，一则挠乱至教，二则劳汝身形。 劳形徒自勤苦，后受不聪明报，好当供养经道，勿复轻忽神灵。 上来劝持经讫，自下举善对恶，以劝取舍。 文为二：前举善恶，以劝取舍； 后劝修道，以明得益。 初文又二：前一行举善劝取，次五行举恶劝舍。 先劝取善。 见有精进者至学故甚不难。 见有精进之人弃俗而修经道，决得升仙度世，然得补天官，高举凌虚，飞行梵外。 修学即得，甚不为难。 此劝取善讫，下劝舍恶。 何为守浊美至独自落天残，此伤时人迷没尘俗，不希腾神轻举，游宴玄都，将隶彼北门，轮回五趣，号啼镬汤之侧，悲叫刀剑之巅，面目困苦，燋燎饥寒，乞食无所，天罚备加，其体受考，弥劫积年。 盖由谤毁贤良，不信宿命，为恶不改，自致天残。 此劝取善拾恶讫，下劝修道。 未若修弘道，众圣与尔群。 未若修经弘道，光显法门，当与得道众真以为朋友。 上来偈诵以劝立功讫，自下结劝修善得益。 文为二：前明自修得益，次劝令尊秘#24。 老君说偈毕，告道陵#25曰：吾昔无鞅数恒#26沙劫无穷无极时，以修此章，歌颂其句，修行礼玩，致得今报。 其趣幽微#27，玄中之玄。 今以告子谛尊之焉，勿以告示不信之人。

This concludes the urging to cultivate and depart from transgressions; below clarifies the benefits gained.

If one can be reverently attentive according to the dharma, then boundless blessings will be received, even to the point of attaining the Dao and ascending to heaven. If one can be reverently attentive according to the dharma, then immeasurable blessings will be received, and the immortal officials who attend the scriptures will naturally come to protect them. Not only will they be free from calamity for the remainder of their lives, but they will even ascend to the heavenly halls.

The preceding long prose passage concludes here. From this point onward, verses are recited to urge the establishment of merit.

Within the verses, there are divisions: first, two and a half lines praise the establishment of merit and the benefits gained.

*"In the world there are the foolish and ignorant..."* (two and a half lines) describe the harm of evil conduct.

*"Those who delight in the dharma..."* (five lines) urge the upholding of the scriptures.

*"Seeing those who are diligent..."* (five and a half lines) present goodness in contrast to evil, urging choice between them.

Now, first recite the upholding of the scriptures:

**Honoring the Void, revering the Great Vehicle—**
**Even demons dare not list their faults.**

Honor the Void and uphold the Great Dharma.
Cut off all glory and desire, and eliminate them entirely.
Once diligence arises within the heart,
What external demon would dare to enumerate their transgressions?

This concludes the urging to establish merit; below clarifies the benefits.

**Transforming misfortune through cultivating virtue—**
**Great merit is thereby accomplished.**

If one can abandon coarse thoughts and reform to cultivate good conduct,
Then past transgressions and debts will naturally dissipate like clouds.
Virtue and power tower majestically, advancing with each passing day.
Transcending the mundane, one ascends lightly,
Utterly distinct from the world.
People must follow this great merit,
For it is thereby accomplished.

This concludes the explanation of the benefits of establishing merit; next clarifies the harm of evil conduct.

*"In the world there are foolish people..."*
Who invoke names to establish ghostly teachings,
Privately deceiving yet openly practicing them—
Ten thousand words, not one is true.

This concludes the explanation of evil conduct; next clarifies the losses incurred.

**Following the heart to perform demonic deeds—**
**Punishment and suffering arrive thus.**

Indulging one’s foolish nature to perform demonic deeds,
Corruption fills and guilt is certain.
Calamity and torment come of their own accord.
Unaware of the day of death’s approach,
Suddenly, brutal violence befalls.
The soul is imprisoned in the ghostly courts of Fengdu,
Where pain and poison reach their peak.

This concludes the explanation of the harm of evil conduct. Below urges the cultivation of the scriptural dharma.

The text is divided into two parts: first, verses praising those who believe in the dharma; then, verses praising those who listen and receive it.

First, recite those who practice the dharma:

**Those who must delight in the dharma,**
**Respect and believe, taking goodness as their cause.**
Though they may not understand the written word,
Their hearts remain sincere and earnest.
They set aside right and wrong,
Listening to and reciting the scriptural passages.

This clarifies belief in the dharma; below clarifies the benefits gained.

**Devoting the heart, the Dao is attained—**
**Virtue and power naturally fill the heavens.**

Devoting the heart, one attains the immortal Dao,
And accomplishes the supreme, perfect truth.
Simply by receiving and upholding the wondrous scriptures,
Virtue and power naturally become vast.

The preceding verses on those who believe and receive conclude here. Below recite those who listen to the dharma:

**All good men and women,**
**Focus your hearts to listen to my scripture.**
Do not face one another with idle chatter,
Nor harbor thoughts of confusion.
First, this disturbs the supreme teachings;
Second, it wearies your bodies.
Wearying the body is but self-inflicted toil,
Later receiving the retribution of dullness.
It is better to honor and serve the scriptural Dao,
And never again slight the divine spirits.

The preceding urging to uphold the scriptures concludes here. Below presents goodness in contrast to evil to urge choice between them.

The text is divided into two: first, presenting good and evil to urge choice; then, urging cultivation of the Dao to clarify the benefits gained.

The first part is further divided: first, one line presents goodness to urge its adoption; then, five lines present evil to urge its abandonment.

First, urging the adoption of goodness:

**Seeing those who are diligent—**
**Learning is thus not at all difficult.**

Seeing those who are diligent,
Abandoning the secular to cultivate the scriptural Dao,
They will surely attain immortality and transcend the world.
Then, they will fill the heavenly offices,
Ascending high and soaring beyond the mundane,
Flying beyond the bounds of the Brahma realms.
Through cultivation and learning, this is attained—
Truly, it is not difficult.

This concludes the urging to adopt goodness; below urges the abandonment of evil.

**Why cling to the impure and beautiful?**
**Alone, you will fall to heavenly ruin.**

This laments that people of this age are submerged in worldly dust,
Not aspiring to ascend in spirit and soar lightly,
Or wander and feast in the mysterious capital.
Instead, they will be bound to the northern gate,
Revolving through the five destinies,
Wailing beside cauldrons of boiling water,
Shrieking atop blades and swords.
Their faces and bodies endure hardship,
Scorched by hunger and cold.
Begging for food, they find no place to turn.
Heavenly punishments are fully applied,
Their bodies suffer torment,
For kalpas upon kalpas, through countless years.
All because they slandered the worthy and good,
Disbelieved in past lives,
Persisted in evil without reform,
And thus brought about their own heavenly ruin.

This concludes the urging to adopt goodness and abandon evil. Below urges cultivation of the Dao:

**Nothing compares to cultivating the great Dao—**
**The host of sages will gather with you.**

Nothing compares to cultivating the scriptures and propagating the Dao,
Illuminating the dharma gate,
So that you may befriend the host of perfected immortals.

The preceding verses urging the establishment of merit conclude here. Below summarizes the urging to cultivate goodness and the benefits gained.

The text is divided into two: first, clarifying the benefits of self-cultivation; then, urging reverence and secrecy.

After Laozi finished reciting the verses, he addressed Daoling, saying:
"In times past, through countless kalpas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, in boundless and limitless eras, I cultivated this chapter, chanting its verses, practicing its rituals, and playing with its words, thereby attaining my present retribution. Its purport is subtle and profound, the mystery within the mystery. Now I tell you this in earnest—revere it well, and do not reveal it to those who lack faith."

chunks.original_text: 若有疑毁者，考及灭门矣。 太上老君告天师曰，我昔无数劫时，以修此经章句，歌颂其义，礼玩策勤，政得今日无上道果。 当知此经理趣深远，玄中之玄。 此举利益讫，下劝尊秘。 今以告子尊之焉，至考及灭门矣。 今以大经宣告於子，子宜谛受，重道殷懃，勿复轻传。 他疑毁之者，考及灭门。 上来至此劝立善功讫，自此已下是前来大段第四文，次劝修经法，亦有长行、偈颂。 就长行文中，又分为二：前举善恶二缘以示，令识人生受命，下次举经戒以劝修行。 初文又二：先物生死之恶，次明报应之事，就前文中分为四：第一明世俗无知，第二明欣恶是等，第三明不得遂心，第四总结劝舍，今先明世俗无知。 老君告道陵曰； 万物之中，人最为贵。 而人处在天地之间，皆知生之日，不知死之日。 善恶之人，富贵贫贱，各愿寿老，谁欲其夭？ 夫死者，人所不乐，而见一切岂能免乎？ 唯有不生，无此难耳。 然此之辈复有因缘，修善得善，其鬼益善； 作恶得恶，其鬼亦恶。 是故半在吾道堂，半在魔地狱。 喻如呼声，莫不有应。 人生寿命#28，制在虚无。 虚无不言，故置圣人。 圣人隐形，遗传经戒。 夫唯经戒，即名道也。 劝人作善，教令修生，一以除过，二致不死； 何但不死，乃成真仙。 如此之福，本非富贵财贿求请能得，本非酒肉祷鬼之所能致； 其唯道士贤者敬奉经戒、勤念所致。 先苦后报，其应明也。 天地所生，唯人为贵。 但愚迷云障，慧识不明，唯知生日富贵，岂知死日早晚。 此明世俗无知讫，次举贵贱同好。 善恶之人至谁欲其夭。 夫人善恶志意同然，皆欲富贵长年，谁愿贫穷夭折。 此明忻恶是等讫，次举不得遂心。 夫死者人所不乐，而见一切岂能免乎。 夫身亡魂逝，人皆恶之，而见一切谁能免此。 下结劝，唯有不生无此。 虽取必欲无死，未若无生。 炼质归真，当有何患？ 上来举生死之乐恶以劝舍讫，此下以明报应事。 然此之辈复有因缘至喻如呼响，莫不有应。 善恶行殊，因缘报别。 是故为鬼不同，升沉各异。 喻如呼响应、种核得果。 此举善恶因缘，示令识悟。 自下正举经法以劝修习，就此文中，分为三别：第一举经以劝，第二明经得益，第三明持经方便。 今先举经以劝。 人生受命制在虚无至夫唯经戒即道也。 人之生世，制在虚无，故置圣人为演经戒。 夫唯经戒，即是於道。 人能弘法，自得道真。 此举经劝讫，次举修经得益。 劝人作善，教令修生，至乃成真仙。 经教之设，本劝修生，人持经，其年自永，何但不死，仍成道真。 此明持经得益讫，下明修习方便。 如此之福，本非富贵财贿求请能得至其应明也，此言其福报，非崇爵巨富所能屈致也，唯有持经奉戒，勤苦自营，福报皎然，明如日月。 上来长行持经讫，自下偈颂以劝持经。 就此文中，分为：前五行劝舍恶以听经，何不勤上道； 下有一行半，劝勤心而革道。 前文又三：一明世俗无知，二明升沉异趣，三劝经法。 於是老君乃说偈曰： 人生最为贵，而不乐法熙，生死随任往，莫知何所之。 冥冥求无知，临报乃悟期。 恶者入三掠，善者获大慈。 若有合真相，听经念善思。 勿复作聋盲，闻法而佯痴。 吾愍诸天人，故留无上辞，作人之大法，为世之良医。
chunks.translated_text:
Should any harbor doubt or slander, their lineage shall be extinguished to the last.

The Most High Lord Lao addressed the Heavenly Master, saying: "In kalpas past beyond count, I cultivated these scriptural verses, chanting their meaning, practicing their rites with diligent devotion, and thus attained the supreme Dao-fruit of this day. Know that the purport of this scripture is profound and far-reaching, the mystery within the mystery."

Here concludes the exposition of its benefits; below urges reverence and secrecy. Now I earnestly tell you—hold it in deepest respect, for the consequences of transgression extend to the annihilation of one’s lineage. This great scripture I now proclaim to you; receive it with utmost care, cherish the Dao with fervent devotion, and transmit it no further. Should others doubt or revile it, their lineage shall be extinguished.

Here ends the urging to establish meritorious deeds. Below begins the fourth major section of the preceding text, which exhorts the method of scripture cultivation, comprising both prose and verse. Within the prose, there are two divisions: first, presenting the dual conditions of good and evil to illustrate human life and destiny; then, setting forth the scriptural precepts to urge cultivation. The first division is further divided into two: first, the evils of life and death; then, the matters of karmic retribution. Within the former, there are four parts: first, the ignorance of the worldly; second, the shared desire for evil; third, the failure to attain one’s desires; fourth, the concluding exhortation to relinquish. We begin with the ignorance of the worldly.

Lord Lao addressed Daoling, saying: "Among the ten thousand things, humans are the most noble. Yet dwelling between Heaven and Earth, all know the day of their birth but not the day of their death. Whether good or evil, wealthy or poor, each wishes for long life—who desires an early demise? Death is what humans do not delight in, yet how can any escape it? Only by not being born can one avoid this difficulty. Yet even this class has its causes and conditions: those who cultivate goodness receive goodness, and their spirits become good; those who commit evil receive evil, and their spirits become evil. Thus, half reside in the halls of my Dao, and half in demonic hells. It is like an echo—none fails to receive a response.

Human lifespan is ordained by the Void. The Void does not speak, so sages were established. Sages concealed their forms, leaving behind scriptures and precepts. These scriptures and precepts are called the Dao. They urge people to do good, teaching them to cultivate life, first to eliminate transgressions, second to attain immortality. Not only does one avoid death, but one becomes a perfected immortal. Such blessings cannot be obtained by seeking wealth or status, nor by offerings of wine and meat to spirits. They arise solely from the reverent observance of scriptures and precepts by worthy Daoists through diligent practice. First suffering, then reward—its response is clear as day.

Of all that Heaven and Earth generate, humans are the most noble. Yet the foolish, clouded by delusion, lack clear wisdom. They know only the day of their birth and their wealth or rank, not the hour of their death."

Here concludes the exposition of worldly ignorance; next, the shared desires of high and low.

"Whether good or evil, all share the same aspirations: to be wealthy, noble, and long-lived. Who would wish for poverty and an early death?"

Here concludes the exposition of shared desires for evil; next, the failure to attain one’s desires.

"Death is what humans do not delight in, yet how can any escape it? The body perishes, the soul departs—all abhor this, yet who can avoid it?"

Below, the concluding exhortation: only by not being born can one avoid this. Though one may seek to avoid death, it is better still not to be born. Refine the body and return to the True—what affliction remains?

Here concludes the exposition of the joys and sorrows of life and death to urge relinquishment; below, the matters of karmic retribution.

"Yet even this class has its causes and conditions—good and evil actions differ, and so do their karmic retributions. Thus, as spirits, their fates diverge, some ascending, some sinking. It is like an echo responding to a call, or a seed yielding its fruit."

This presents the causes and conditions of good and evil to awaken understanding. Below, the proper exposition of scriptural methods to urge cultivation. Within this section, there are three divisions: first, presenting the scriptures to urge; second, clarifying the benefits of the scriptures; third, explaining the methods of upholding the scriptures. We begin with presenting the scriptures to urge.

"Human life is ordained by the Void, so sages were established to expound scriptures and precepts. These scriptures and precepts are the Dao itself. Those who propagate the Dharma thereby attain the True Dao."

Here concludes the presentation of the scriptures to urge; next, the benefits of cultivating the scriptures.

"Urging people to do good and teaching them to cultivate life—those who uphold the scriptures prolong their years. Not only do they avoid death, but they attain the True Dao and become immortals."

Here concludes the exposition of the benefits of upholding the scriptures; below, the methods of cultivation.

"Such blessings cannot be obtained by seeking wealth or status, nor by offerings to spirits. Only through upholding the scriptures, observing the precepts, and enduring hardship in self-cultivation does the reward become as radiant as the sun and moon."

Here concludes the prose on upholding the scriptures; below, verses exhort the same. Within this section, there are two parts: first, five lines urging the abandonment of evil to heed the scriptures—*Why not diligently ascend the Dao?*; then, one and a half lines urging diligent devotion to reform the Dao. The first part is further divided into three: first, the ignorance of the worldly; second, the divergent fates of ascent and descent; third, the exhortation to the scriptural Dharma.

Thus, Lord Lao spoke in verse:

"Humans are the most noble,
Yet take no joy in the Dharma’s splendor.
Life and death follow their course,
None know where they shall go.
In darkness they seek without knowing,
Only at retribution’s hour do they awaken.
The wicked enter the three torments,
The good obtain great mercy.
If one accords with the True,
Hear the scriptures, contemplate goodness.
Do not feign deafness and blindness,
Hearing the Dharma yet pretending folly.
I pity all heavenly and mortal beings,
Thus I leave these supreme words,
The great Dharma for humanity,
The excellent physician for the world."

chunks.original_text: 财贿当法用，勿以祷邪祠。 万万无一报，妖炁殃日滋。 何不勤上道，见法生心谋#29。 恶者报亦恶，未若立善基。 苦行得甘报，自然登玄台。 已前颂世俗无知，人生最为贵，至临报乃悟。 明天地之间，唯人为贵，何不勤修经，清净喜熙。 而乃任命死生莫知何趣，冥冥长夜，临报始知。 此明世俗无知讫，次辩升沈有异，恶者入三掠，善者获大慈。 恶者入於地狱，一日三掠形魂； 善者上升天堂，大圣慈悲接引。 此明升沈异趣讫，次劝听法。 若有合真相，听经念善思，至妖炁殃日滋。 若有合真相者，当须思善听经，勿复诈作聋盲，闻法佯痴不解。 大圣愍诸天人，故留无上妙教，为人作於大法，为世作以良医。 有财当从道用，勿复祷鬼祠邪，万万终无一报，妖炁日日滋生。 此劝舍恶讫，次劝修道。 何不劝上至道自然登玄台。 因何不勤修上道，见法心即谋从。 行恶则得恶报，未若建立善基，苦行报自甘，萧然玄台之上。 上来至此劝持经法讫，自此以下是前来大段第二文，次劝持五戒。 就此文中，自有长行、偈颂。 就长行文中，分为五别：第一举恶劝舍，第二举戒劝修，第三明持戒得益，第四明违者有失，第五劝令秘慎。 今先劝舍恶。 道言：夫色欲败事，最不可行#30，而世间贤愚贵贱皆亦同愿。 唯有道士乃能执志，坚持教戒，以自检缚，行止举动，心不倾邪，在於爱欲之间，初不一违。 若见色利、荣华粲彩，以戒掩目； 若闻好恶之言、五音之属，以戒塞耳； 若有八珍之馔、甘香之美，以戒杜口； 若愿想财货、七宝奇珍，放情极欲，以戒挫心； 若意奸淫、贪趣恶事，以戒折足。 能行此五者，七祖生天，衣食自然，身得神仙，白日登晨。 如其尸解，转轮成真。 贤者精诚奉持之也。 若男若女不能承用，不肯受持，无可如何，吾宁与人万金，不书此言。 道陵，子当择其人而授，勿泄真文。 染滞情色，败己亡身。 世俗之人不能拾远此。 举恶劝拾讫，次举戒劝修。 先出持戒人，次出所持之戒。 惟有道士，至不一违； 惟有道士，独能晓悟，坚持教戒，检束身心，纵在爱欲之中，未曾违犯。 此出持戒人讫，次出所持之戒。 若见色利荣华粲彩至以戒折足。 若见美色荣华、朗黄粲彩，以戒掩目，莫令眼看； 若闻五音、淫声妖乐，以戒塞闭耳，莫令耳闻； 若遇八珍、甘香美馔，以戒杜口，莫令口尝； 若想钱财、奇珍异货，以戒挫心，防意止想； 若念奸淫、贪趣恶事，以戒折足，使足莫行。 辩戒讫，次辩持戒。 得能行此五事讫，次明违者有失。 若男女不能承用至不书此言。 伤叹时人贵财贱道，故发此言。 相与沈沦，奈何哉。 此明违戒有失讫，次劝传授。 道陵，子当择人而授，勿泄真文。 若有敬信之人具上十相，来欲请受，先赍信金、诚素，试之无退，将经付之。 必其犹豫猜疑，秘而莫与。 此长行讫，下举偈颂。 就偈颂文中，为四别：第一有三行半颂，不持戒者有损； 第二有三行半颂，持戒者得益； 第三有三行颂，能离五种之恶； 第四有两行半颂，改过得益。 太上老君仍说偈曰： 欲欲是何物？ 悉从心中生。

Wealth and bribes should be used in accordance with the Dao,
Do not pray to deviant shrines.
Ten million times, not a single return,
While malevolent qi brings daily increasing calamity.
Why not diligently follow the Supreme Dao,
Seeing the Dharma and devising plans in the heart?

The wicked receive wicked retribution,
Yet it is better to establish a foundation of goodness.
Through苦行 one obtains sweet reward,
Naturally ascending the Mystic Terrace.

The preceding verses admonish the ignorance of the worldly,
That humans are most noble,
Yet only at retribution’s hour do they awaken.
Between Heaven and Earth,
Only humans are noble—
Why not diligently cultivate the scriptures,
Delighting in purity and splendor?
Instead, they surrender to fate, unaware of life and death’s course,
Wandering in endless darkness,
Only realizing at retribution’s hour.

This concludes the exposition on the ignorance of the worldly.
Next, it distinguishes the divergent fates of ascent and descent:
The wicked enter the three torments,
The good obtain great mercy.
The wicked descend into hell,
Where body and soul suffer thrice daily;
The good ascend to heaven,
Where the Great Sage, in compassion, welcomes and guides them.

This concludes the distinction of divergent fates.
Next, it exhorts listening to the Dharma:
If one accords with the True,
Hearing the scriptures and contemplating goodness,
To the point of "malevolent qi brings daily increasing calamity."
If one accords with the True,
One must contemplate goodness and listen to the scriptures,
Never feigning deafness and blindness,
Hearing the Dharma yet pretending folly.

The Great Sage pities all heavenly and mortal beings,
Thus leaving these supreme teachings,
The great Dharma for humanity,
The excellent physician for the world.
Wealth should be used in accordance with the Dao,
Never praying to deviant shrines or spirits.
Ten million times, there is no return,
While malevolent qi grows daily.

This concludes the exhortation to abandon evil;
Next, it urges cultivation of the Dao:
Why not strive for the Supreme Dao,
Naturally ascending the Mystic Terrace?
Why not diligently cultivate the Supreme Dao,
Seeing the Dharma and devising plans in the heart?
Acting wickedly brings wicked retribution—
Better to establish a foundation of goodness.
Through苦行, the reward is naturally sweet,
Serenely upon the Mystic Terrace.

Thus far, the exhortation to uphold the scriptural Dharma concludes.
Hereafter begins the second major section,
Which urges adherence to the Five Precepts.
Within this section, there are both prose and verse.
In the prose, five distinctions are made:
First, citing evil to urge its abandonment;
Second, citing the precepts to urge cultivation;
Third, clarifying the benefits of upholding the precepts;
Fourth, clarifying the losses of transgressors;
Fifth, exhorting secrecy and caution.

First, urging the abandonment of evil:
The Dao states: Sensual desire ruins affairs—
It must not be indulged.
Yet all in the world, wise or foolish, noble or base, share the same desires.
Only Daoists can hold fast to their resolve,
Firmly upholding the teachings and precepts,
Restraining themselves,
In conduct and movement, their hearts never inclining toward deviance.
Amidst love and desire,
They never transgress even once.
When they see beauty, profit, glory, or dazzling splendor,
They cover their eyes with the precepts;
When they hear praise or blame, or the five tones,
They seal their ears with the precepts;
When they encounter the eight delicacies or sweet, fragrant delicacies,
They shut their mouths with the precepts;
When they crave wealth, the seven treasures, or rare jewels,
Indulging their passions to excess,
They subdue their hearts with the precepts;
When their minds incline toward lewdness or covetous, wicked deeds,
They break their feet with the precepts.

Those who can practice these five
Will cause their seven ancestors to be born in heaven,
Clothed and fed naturally,
Their bodies attaining immortality,
Ascending at dawn in broad daylight.
If they undergo liberation by means of the corpse,
They will transform and become perfected.
The worthy, with sincere devotion, uphold these precepts.
If men or women cannot accept and practice them,
There is nothing to be done—
I would rather give someone ten thousand gold pieces
Than write these words.

Dao-ling, you must choose whom to transmit this to,
Do not leak the true scripture.
Attachment to sensual desire and emotion
Destroys oneself and ruins the body.
Worldly people cannot relinquish these.
This concludes the urging to abandon evil;
Next, citing the precepts to urge cultivation.

First, describing the upholder of the precepts,
Then, the precepts themselves.
Only Daoists,
To the point of "never transgressing even once";
Only Daoists,
Alone able to awaken and understand,
Firmly upholding the teachings and precepts,
Restraining body and mind,
Even amidst love and desire,
Never violating them.

This concludes the description of the upholder of the precepts;
Next, the precepts themselves:
When seeing beauty, profit, glory, or dazzling splendor,
Cover the eyes with the precepts, allowing no gaze;
When hearing the five tones, lewd sounds, or seductive music,
Seal the ears with the precepts, allowing no hearing;
When encountering the eight delicacies or sweet, fragrant dishes,
Shut the mouth with the precepts, allowing no tasting;
When desiring money, rare treasures, or exotic goods,
Subdue the heart with the precepts, restraining thoughts and desires;
When inclined toward lewdness or covetous, wicked deeds,
Break the feet with the precepts, preventing them from moving.

This concludes the explanation of the precepts;
Next, the benefits of upholding them.
Having described the practice of these five,
Next, the losses of transgressors:
If men or women cannot accept and practice them,
To the point of "I would rather give someone ten thousand gold pieces than write these words."
Lamenting that people of the age value wealth and despise the Dao,
Thus these words are spoken.
Together they sink and drown—what can be done?
This concludes the explanation of the losses of transgressors;
Next, exhorting transmission.

Dao-ling, you must choose whom to transmit this to,
Do not leak the true scripture.
If a person of reverence and faith,
Possessing the ten superior qualities,
Comes seeking to receive it,
First offer gold as a token of sincerity,
Test them to ensure no retreat,
Then entrust the scripture to them.
If they hesitate or doubt,
Keep it secret and do not transmit it.

This concludes the prose;
Below are the verses.
In the verses, four distinctions are made:
First, three and a half lines on the losses of those who do not uphold the precepts;
Second, three and a half lines on the benefits of upholding the precepts;
Third, three lines on abandoning the five kinds of evil;
Fourth, two and a half lines on the benefits of reforming transgressions.

The Most High Lord Lao then spoke in verse:

"What is desire?
It all arises from the heart."

chunks.original_text: 目睹荣丽色，耳洞五音声，口甘八珍味#31，心想财自荣，意贪淫奸事，手足为之行。 五恶既不住，考对在兆形，永与生道隔，幽魂没鬼图。 罪毕出在所#32，有人而无情。 奉戒不行恶，掩塞五心门，目不视绮容，耳不采声烦，口不飨甘美，心不爱钱财#33，意无淫向想，手足不为申。 五恶寂住停，考对焉从宣？ 永与真道合，不复零鬼官。 功积从戒起，白日登玉晨。 目以色为仇，初不欲一见； 耳以音为雠，初不愿欲闻； 口以味为苦，初不以自熏； 心以宝为咎，初不为想恋； 意以奸为贼，初不欲同贯； 足以夷为阻，初不乐涉端。 五苦同一路，初不倾邪看。 若能如是者，所谓妙中难。 难中既能通，滓滞无由安。 身清神则宁，皇一守丹田。 行备由因起#34，致得升冲天。 欲欲是何物、悉从心中生者，上欲是态欲之心，下欲是所贪之境。 此之二心，从何而起？ 悉是己身颠倒妄想。 此总举讫，下别列。 目睹荣丽色至手足为之行。 目则妄瞻五色，耳则通取五声，口则珍味甘脆，心则经营贿货，意既贪求恶事，手足即为之行。 此明为恶讫，下明损失。 五欲既不住至有人而无情。 五心起欲不住，灾考对在兆形，永与长生道隔，幽魂没鬼囹圄，罪毕，纵其得出受形，六情不具。 此明违戒获损讫，下明持戒得益。 奉戒不行恶，掩塞五欲心门，此总举。 讫，下别：目不睹绮容至手足不为申。 目不睹色，耳不采声，口不尝甘，心不受货，乃至意无外想，足不妄行。 此明持戒讫，下明得益。 五恶寂住停至白日登玉晨。 五心既其停住，考对焉得妄加，永与真道合同，不复沦於鬼府。 积功从戒而起，白日上升玉京。 此明持戒得益讫，次辩能离五种。 目以色为仇至初不乐涉端。 目以色为怨仇，初不将眼一见； 耳以声为雠隙，初不令耳一闻； 口不味於美甘，心不恋於金玉，乃至意无淫想，不与奸恶同群； 手足平夷，未曾涉行阻难。 此明能离五种讫，下明得益。 五者同一路，初不倾邪看，至故前能升冲天。 上来五欲同起一心，初不倾邪，妄有缘者，若能如是舍离，所谓妙中之难。 难中既能通，滓滞无由得住，身清神则宁，皇人安住丹田。 行备因戒而来，故政得冲虚之道。 上来至此明持戒得益讫，自此以下是大段第六，总劝持经修行，以明得益。 就此文中，分为四别：第一修行以舍恶，第二建志以持经，第三修经得益，第四戒勿轻传。 前文又二：前劝修道，次劝去邪。 但劝存道。 道言：奉法修道当勤，修身当坚，精进当久，持戒当固，专念当执，谛想莫不存道，去邪去惑，去妖去伪，去淫去欲，除弃众非，以为抱真致得升冲#35。 是先劳后报，度身升仙，当期当来，勿睹目前。 夫恶无交祸，善无近福。 子善思惟，庄事勤身，效力奉持经法。 此经高妙，综统三洞，无上至真第一玄章。 受持之者，人中无上。 自无玄名，万无一见。
chunks.translated_text:
The eyes behold radiant beauty,
The ears drink in the five tones,
The mouth savors the eight delicacies,
The heart covets wealth and glory,
The mind lusts after lewd and wicked deeds,
The hands and feet carry them out.

When the five evils are not restrained,
Judgment appears in the omen’s form,
Forever cut off from the Way of life,
The dark soul sinks into the ghostly prison.
When the sentence is served and they emerge,
They are human in form but lack feeling.

Those who uphold the precepts and do no evil
Seal the five gates of the heart:
The eyes do not gaze on alluring appearances,
The ears do not seek clamorous sounds,
The mouth does not feast on sweet delights,
The heart does not love money and wealth,
The mind harbors no impure thoughts,
The hands and feet do not act on them.

When the five evils are stilled and cease,
How can judgment be pronounced?
Forever united with the true Dao,
No longer do they fall to the ghostly officials.
Merit accumulates from the precepts,
And they ascend in broad daylight to the Jade Dawn.

The eye treats beauty as an enemy,
Never wishing to see it once;
The ear treats sound as a foe,
Never desiring to hear it;
The mouth treats flavor as bitterness,
Never allowing itself to be tainted;
The heart treats treasure as fault,
Never indulging in longing;
The mind treats wickedness as a thief,
Never wishing to share its path;
The feet treat the level path as an obstacle,
Never delighting to tread its course.

The five sufferings share one road,
Never inclining toward perverse views.
Those who can do this
Are called the rarest of the rare.
Having mastered what is difficult,
Impurities have no place to linger.
The body is pure, the spirit at peace,
The August One guards the cinnabar field.
Conduct perfected arises from cause,
Thus they ascend to the heavens above.

"What is desire?
It all arises from the heart."
The first "desire" refers to the mind of covetousness,
The second "desire" to the objects of greed.
From where do these two minds arise?
All from one’s own inverted and deluded thoughts.

This concludes the general statement;
Below are the particulars.
From "The eyes behold radiant beauty" to "the hands and feet carry them out":
The eyes recklessly gaze on the five colors,
The ears indiscriminately take in the five sounds,
The mouth relishes rich and crisp flavors,
The heart schemes for bribes and goods,
The mind, lusting after evil deeds,
The hands and feet then carry them out.

This clarifies the commission of evil;
Below, the losses are made clear.
From "When the five evils are not restrained" to "they are human in form but lack feeling":
When the five desires of the heart are unrestrained,
Disaster and judgment appear in the omen’s form,
Forever cut off from the Way of long life,
The dark soul sinks into the ghostly prison.
When the sentence is served and they emerge to receive form,
Their six senses are incomplete.

This concludes the explanation of the harm from violating the precepts;
Below, the benefits of upholding the precepts are made clear.
"Those who uphold the precepts and do no evil,
Seal the five gates of desire"—this is the general statement.
Below are the particulars:
From "The eyes do not gaze on alluring appearances" to "the hands and feet do not act on them":
The eyes do not behold beauty,
The ears do not seek sounds,
The mouth does not taste sweetness,
The heart does not accept wealth,
Even the mind harbors no external thoughts,
The feet do not wander recklessly.

This concludes the explanation of upholding the precepts;
Below, the benefits are made clear.
From "When the five evils are stilled and cease" to "they ascend in broad daylight to the Jade Dawn":
When the five desires of the heart are stilled and cease,
How can judgment be falsely imposed?
Forever united with the true Dao,
No longer do they sink into the ghostly prison.
Merit accumulates from the precepts,
And they ascend in broad daylight to the Jade Capital.

This concludes the explanation of the benefits of upholding the precepts;
Next, the ability to abandon the five kinds of evil is expounded.
From "The eye treats beauty as an enemy" to "never delighting to tread its course":
The eye treats beauty as an enemy,
Never allowing itself a single glance;
The ear treats sound as a foe,
Never permitting itself to hear;
The mouth finds flavor bitter,
Never allowing itself to be tainted;
The heart treats treasure as fault,
Never indulging in longing;
The mind treats wickedness as a thief,
Never wishing to share its path;
The feet treat the level path as an obstacle,
Never delighting to tread its course.

This concludes the explanation of abandoning the five kinds of evil;
Below, the benefits are made clear.
From "The five sufferings share one road" to "thus they ascend to the heavens above":
The five desires arise from one mind,
Never inclining toward perverse and deluded attachments.
Those who can thus abandon them
Are called the rarest of the rare.
Having mastered what is difficult,
Impurities have no place to linger.
The body is pure, the spirit at peace,
The August One abides in the cinnabar field.
Conduct perfected arises from the precepts,
Thus they attain the Way of soaring emptiness.

This concludes the explanation of the benefits of upholding the precepts.
From here onward is the sixth major section,
Which exhorts the upholding of the scripture and cultivation of practice,
To clarify the benefits.
Within this text, there are four distinctions:
First, cultivation of practice to abandon evil;
Second, establishing resolve to uphold the scripture;
Third, the benefits of practicing the scripture;
Fourth, a warning against careless transmission.

The preceding text has two parts:
First, an exhortation to cultivate the Dao;
Next, an exhortation to abandon evil.
It speaks only of preserving the Dao:
"In upholding the Dharma and cultivating the Dao, be diligent;
In cultivating the body, be steadfast;
In advancing, be enduring;
In upholding the precepts, be firm;
In focused thought, be unwavering;
In careful contemplation, never depart from the Dao.
Abandon evil, abandon delusion,
Abandon demonic influences, abandon deceit,
Abandon lewdness, abandon desire,
Cast aside all wrongdoing,
Thus embracing the true to attain ascent to the heavens.
This is to labor first and receive reward later,
To transcend the mortal body and ascend as an immortal.
Look to the future, not merely the present.
Evil brings no immediate calamity,
Good brings no immediate blessing.
Reflect carefully on this,
Devote yourself earnestly to the task,
Exert your strength in upholding the scripture and Dharma."

This scripture is lofty and wondrous,
Encompassing the Three Caverns,
The supreme, most true, and foremost mysterious chapter.
Those who receive and uphold it
Are unexcelled among humanity.
Without the mysterious name,
Not one in ten thousand will see it.

chunks.original_text: 有心之者，当如饥渴得饮食，如寒得冬衣，若凉得春服； 当如贫人得宝，贱人得官。 如作极须消息，疲劳欲睡寐； 如愿想，欲有所得。 得此经法，当作此念，勤苦如法，福报无量矣。 此经度人无数，修道诵之，得成真人； 畏怖诵之，魔不犯身； 疾病诵之，立起死魂； 忧恼诵之，自然喜欢； 县官诵之，得停狱门。 若为亡人诵之，休息宁闲； 贫穷诵之，保宜财钱； 命厄诵之，普皆寿延； 愚暗诵之，心聪圣贤。 一人诵之，福周九亲，度人无量，润流十天，无上无下，无大无小，无边无际，皆蒙慈恩。 子等秘之，慎勿妄宣。 泄慢经文，授非其人，则考有风刀，身没鬼官。 兆宜慎之，吾不虚言。 道陵稽首礼谢而去。 夫欲奉持经戒，学道修身，当坚固精诚，专念谛想，行住坐卧，以道为心。 此劝存念讫，次劝去邪去惑，去妖去伪，至勿睹目前，当去六种众非，包含真性。 先虽劳苦，后获升仙。 当期未来善报，勿睹目前快乐。 此劝舍恶讫，次劝持经。 就为三别：第一正劝，第二举喻以劝，第三合喻。 前文又二：初劝持经，次叹经尊胜。 今是初。 夫恶无友祸，善无近福，至奉受经法。 但福报善移，不必同至。 好当庄事，勤身奉受经法。 此劝受经讫，次叹法。 此经高妙综统至万无一见。 此经三洞之上，统御万灵，无上至真，微妙第一。 法既尊高，受者亦贵。 无玄名仙骨，终不遭遇此经。 此叹法竟，下举喻有心之人，当如饥渴欲得饮食，至愿想欲有所得。 此举喻讫，下结成，见此经法，当作此念，至福报无量矣。 上来八念，但能勤苦如法，则受福无穷。 此劝持经诵。 次劝得益。 此经度人无数量，至福周九亲。 此经有十福利益竟，次明功德广远。 度人无量，恩流十天，至皆蒙慈恩。 此经功不可思议，福润十天，泽流万境，无上无下，无际无边，尽沐斯恩，皆浃巨福。 此叹经利益竟，下戒勿轻传。 子等秘之，慎勿妄宣，至吾不虚言。 子宜尊秘，择人而传，勿复妄宣，招於罪失。 此设戒讫，次天师领教，道陵稽首礼谢而去。 上来一卷辩中和行讫，自此已下更会蓬莱，为说显真大哉。 太上灵宝升玄内教经中和品述义疏竟 #1财：原作『而』。 兹据敦煌P.3341改。 （以下简称敦煌本） #2手：敦煌本作『首』。 #3光：敦煌本作『芳』。 #4千：敦煌本作「亿」。 #5愿：敦煌本作「履」。 #6原无『尔』，兹据敦煌本补。 #7梵天：敦煌本作「神天」。 #8官符：敦煌本作『非横』。 #9老君：敦煌本作『道君』（以下同，如『太上老君』作『太上道君』）。 #10谓：原作『诸』。 兹据敦煌本改。

Those with sincere intent should approach this as one parched and starving seeks food and drink, as one freezing seeks winter garments, or one sweltering seeks spring raiment; as the destitute finding treasure, or the lowly attaining rank. As one toiling desperately seeks rest, weary and longing for sleep; as one yearning, desiring fulfillment. Upon obtaining this scripture and Dharma, cultivate this resolve: endure hardship in accordance with the Dao, and boundless blessings shall follow.

This scripture has delivered countless souls. Those who cultivate the Dao and recite it shall attain the rank of Perfected; those in fear and reciting it shall be untouched by demons; the ill reciting it shall rise from their deathbeds; the distressed reciting it shall find natural joy; officials reciting it shall see their prison gates stay closed. If recited for the deceased, they shall rest in peace; the impoverished reciting it shall secure wealth; those facing mortal peril reciting it shall all have their lives extended; the ignorant reciting it shall gain wisdom and sagacity.

One who recites it bestows blessings upon nine generations of kin, delivers limitless beings, and nourishes the Ten Heavens. Without distinction of high or low, great or small, boundless and infinite, all receive the grace of compassion. You must guard this secret—take care not to recklessly disseminate it. To carelessly reveal the scripture or transmit it to the unworthy invites the judgment of wind-knives and consignment to the courts of ghosts. You would do well to heed this; my words are not empty.

Dao Ling bowed in reverence, expressed gratitude, and departed.

Those who wish to uphold the scriptural precepts, study the Dao, and cultivate the body must fortify their resolve with sincerity, focus their thoughts with clarity, and keep the Dao in their hearts whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down. This admonition to maintain mindfulness is followed by the exhortation to abandon evil and delusion, demonic influences and deceit, to the point of not being swayed by immediate pleasures. One must cast aside the six kinds of wrongdoing and embrace the true nature. Though the labor comes first, ascension to immortality follows. One should anticipate future rewards rather than seek present gratification.

This exhortation to forsake evil is followed by the encouragement to uphold the scriptures. It is divided into three parts: first, a direct exhortation; second, an illustrative exhortation; and third, a synthesis of the analogy. The preceding text is further divided: first, the encouragement to uphold the scriptures, then the praise of the scripture’s exalted virtue.

Here begins the first part. Though evil brings no immediate calamity and good no immediate blessing, the transformation wrought by blessings and virtue is inevitable. One should therefore devote oneself earnestly to receiving the scriptural Dharma. This concludes the encouragement to receive the scriptures, followed by praise of the Dharma.

This scripture is lofty and wondrous, encompassing the Three Caverns, supreme and most true, the foremost of the mysterious. As the scripture is exalted, so too are those who receive it. Without the mysterious name and the bone of an immortal, one will never encounter this scripture. This concludes the praise of the Dharma. Below, an analogy is drawn: those with sincere intent should be like one parched and starving seeking food and drink, to the point of yearning for fulfillment. This concludes the analogy, followed by the synthesis: upon seeing this scripture and Dharma, one should cultivate this resolve, enduring hardship in accordance with the Dao, and boundless blessings shall follow.

The eight contemplations above, if pursued with diligence and in accordance with the Dao, will bring limitless blessings. This concludes the encouragement to uphold and recite the scriptures, followed by the enumeration of its benefits.

This scripture has delivered countless beings, and its ten blessings are as follows: those who cultivate the Dao and recite it attain the rank of Perfected; those in fear reciting it are untouched by demons; the ill reciting it rise from their deathbeds; the distressed reciting it find natural joy; officials reciting it see their prison gates stay closed; if recited for the deceased, they rest in peace; the impoverished reciting it secure wealth; those facing mortal peril reciting it have their lives extended; the ignorant reciting it gain wisdom and sagacity; and one who recites it bestows blessings upon nine generations of kin. This concludes the ten blessings of the scripture, followed by the expounding of its vast and far-reaching merits.

It delivers limitless beings, its grace flows through the Ten Heavens, without distinction of high or low, boundless and infinite, all bathed in its compassion. The blessings of this scripture are beyond comprehension, nourishing the Ten Heavens and flowing through all realms. This concludes the praise of the scripture’s benefits, followed by the warning against careless transmission.

You must guard this secret—take care not to recklessly disseminate it. To carelessly reveal the scripture or transmit it to the unworthy invites the judgment of wind-knives and consignment to the courts of ghosts. You would do well to heed this; my words are not empty. This concludes the warning, followed by the Heavenly Master’s reception of the teaching. Dao Ling bowed in reverence, expressed gratitude, and departed.

Here concludes the scroll on the "Harmonious Practice" of the *Supreme Pervading Mystery Inner Teachings of the Numinous Treasure*. Next, the assembly shall convene at Penglai, where the revelation of the great and manifest truth shall be expounded.

The Way of Heaven and Earth is boundless,
The mud-pill palace of the head is void and empty.
If you have not once vowed to uphold the precepts,
How can you hope to hear and recite the scriptures and commandments?
